If `m` and `n` are natural numbers, then the natural number `m^n` is even
if and only if `m` is even and `n` is positive.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m ^ n) ↔ Even m ∧ n ≠ 0
name: Nat.even_pow
docString:
If `m` and `n` are natural numbers, then the natural number `m^n` is even
if and only if `m` is even and `n` is positive.

For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: For all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n-1` is an even number. Equivalently, the product of two consecutive natural numbers is an even number.

This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, the number is either even or odd. A natural number `n` is defined as even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers, and as odd if it can be expressed as `2*k + 1` for some number `k`. Thus, the theorem asserts that any natural number fits one of these two definitions.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Even n ∨ Odd n
name: Nat.even_or_odd
docString: This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, the number is either even or odd. A natural number `n` is defined as even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers, and as odd if it can be expressed as `2*k + 1` for some number `k`. Thus, the theorem asserts that any natural number fits one of these two definitions.

A natural number `n` is even if and only if `n` modulo 2 equals 0.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, Even n ↔ n % 2 = 0
statement: theorem Nat.even_iff : ∀ {n : ℕ}, Even n ↔ n % 2 = 0 := by sorry
name: Nat.even_iff
description: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, `n` is even if and only if the remainder when `n` is divided by 2 equals 0. In other words, this theorem provides a condition to check the evenness of a number in terms of a modular arithmetic operation. Specifically, a natural number `n` satisfies `Even n` (meaning there exists a natural number `r` such that `n = r + r`) if and only if `n` modulo 2 equals zero.
concise-description: A natural number `n` is even if and only if `n` modulo 2 equals 0.

The sum of two natural numbers is even if and only if both numbers are even or both are odd.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m + n) ↔ (Even m ↔ Even n)
statement: theorem Nat.even_add : ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m + n) ↔ (Even m ↔ Even n) := by sorry
name: Nat.even_add
description: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, the sum `m + n` is even if and only if `m` and `n` are both even or both odd. In other words, the parity of the sum of two natural numbers is the same as the parity of the individual numbers. Here, `Even` is a property of a number that is defined to be true if the number can be expressed as the sum of two equal numbers.
concise-description: The sum of two natural numbers is even if and only if both numbers are even or both are odd.

`choose n 2` is the `n`-th triangle number.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Nat.choose n 2 = n * (n - 1) / 2
name: Nat.choose_two_right

For any natural number n, the remainder of n when divided by 2 is either 0 or 1. (Equivalently, every natural number is either even or odd.)

name: Nat.mod_two_eq_zero_or_one
docString: For any natural number n, the remainder of n when divided by 2 is either 0 or 1. (Equivalently, every natural number is either even or odd.)

This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, `n` is even if and only if `n` is not odd. Here, a number is defined as being even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers, and as being odd if it can be represented as `2*k + 1` for some natural number `k`. In other words, a natural number cannot be both even and odd simultaneously.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, Even n ↔ ¬Odd n
name: Nat.even_iff_not_odd
docString: This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, `n` is even if and only if `n` is not odd. Here, a number is defined as being even if it can be expressed as the sum of two identical numbers, and as being odd if it can be represented as `2*k + 1` for some natural number `k`. In other words, a natural number cannot be both even and odd simultaneously.

Every integer can be classified as even (being expressible as 2*r for some integer r) or odd (being expressible as 2*k + 1 for some integer k).

type: ∀ (n : ℤ), Even n ∨ Odd n
statement: theorem Int.even_or_odd : ∀ (n : ℤ), Even n ∨ Odd n := by sorry
name: Int.even_or_odd
description: This theorem states that for every integer `n`, `n` is either even or odd. In the context of the defined terms, an integer is even if it can be expressed as twice some integer, i.e., `n = 2*r` for some integer `r`. On the other hand, an integer is odd if it can be expressed in the form `n = 2*k + 1` for some integer `k`. This theorem is a reflection of the fundamental dichotomy of integers into even and odd numbers.
concise-description: Every integer can be classified as even (being expressible as 2*r for some integer r) or odd (being expressible as 2*k + 1 for some integer k).

If `n` is even and `a` is even, then `n % a` is even.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even n → Even a → Even (n % a)
name: Even.mod_even
docString: If `n` is even and `a` is even, then `n % a` is even.

A natural number `n` is odd if and only if it cannot be expressed as the sum of two equal natural numbers. Equivalently, it is odd if and only if it is of the form `2*k + 1` for some natural number `k`.

type: ∀ {α : Sort u_1} {a b : α}, (a = b) = (b = a)
name: Mathlib.Data.Nat.Parity._auxLemma.4
docString: A natural number `n` is odd if and only if it cannot be expressed as the sum of two equal natural numbers. Equivalently, it is odd if and only if it is of the form `2*k + 1` for some natural number `k`.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "∀ n ∈ ℕ, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Even (n * (n - 1))
name: Nat.even_mul_self_pred
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `n`, the product of `n` and `n - 1` is an even number. In mathematical terms, this theorem can be written as: "∀ n ∈ ℕ, n*(n - 1) is even." Here, a number is considered even if it can be expressed as twice another number, in this case, n*(n - 1) = 2*r for some `r`.

A natural number is odd if and only if it is not even, or equivalently, a natural number is odd if and only if it can be expressed as 2 times an integer plus one, while an even number can be expressed as the sum of two integers.

type: ∀ {n : ℕ}, Odd n ↔ ¬Even n
statement: theorem Nat.odd_iff_not_even : ∀ {n : ℕ}, Odd n ↔ ¬Even n := by sorry
name: Nat.odd_iff_not_even
description: This theorem states that for every natural number `n`, `n` being odd is equivalent to `n` not being even. In other words, a natural number is odd if and only if it is not even. Here, a number is considered odd if it can be expressed as `2*k + 1` for some `k`, and a number is considered even if it can be written as `r + r` for some `r`.
concise-description: A natural number is odd if and only if it is not even, or equivalently, a natural number is odd if and only if it can be expressed as 2 times an integer plus one, while an even number can be expressed as the sum of two integers.

`n` is a prime power if there is a prime `p` and a positive natural `k` such that `n` can be
written as `p^k`.

type: {R : Type u_1} → [inst : CommMonoidWithZero R] → R → Prop
name: IsPrimePow
docString:
`n` is a prime power if there is a prime `p` and a positive natural `k` such that `n` can be
written as `p^k`.

For any natural numbers n and a, n is even if and only if a is even implies the remainder of n divided by a is even.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even a → (Even (n % a) ↔ Even n)
name: Even.mod_even_iff
docString: For any natural numbers n and a, n is even if and only if a is even implies the remainder of n divided by a is even.

This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, the number `n + 1` is even if and only if `n` is not even. In other words, if `n` is an odd number, then `n + 1` is an even number, and vice versa.

type: ∀ {m n : ℕ}, Even (m + n) = (Even m ↔ Even n)
name: Mathlib.Data.Nat.Parity._auxLemma.13
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `n`, the number `n + 1` is even if and only if `n` is not even. In other words, if `n` is an odd number, then `n + 1` is an even number, and vice versa.

Count the number of naturals `k < n` satisfying `p k`.

type: (p : ℕ → Prop) → [inst : DecidablePred p] → ℕ → ℕ
name: Nat.count
docString: Count the number of naturals `k < n` satisfying `p k`.

If `a` is even, then `n` is even iff `n % a` is even.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even a → (Even (n % a) ↔ Even n)
name: Even.mod_even_iff
docString: If `a` is even, then `n` is even iff `n % a` is even.

If `n : ℕ+` is different from `1`, then it is the successor of some `k : ℕ+`.

name: PNat.exists_eq_succ_of_ne_one
docString: If `n : ℕ+` is different from `1`, then it is the successor of some `k : ℕ+`.

If `s` is an infinite set of natural numbers and `k > 0`, then `s` contains two elements `m < n`
that are equal mod `k`.

type: ∀ {s : Set ℕ}, Set.Infinite s → ∀ {k : ℕ}, 0 < k → ∃ m ∈ s, ∃ n ∈ s, m < n ∧ m ≡ n [MOD k]
name: Nat.exists_lt_modEq_of_infinite
docString:
If `s` is an infinite set of natural numbers and `k > 0`, then `s` contains two elements `m < n`
that are equal mod `k`.
